Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: They plan to attend a family ceremony, making sure to arrive on time and wear appropriate attire.
Story: I stared at my phone, thumb hovering over the screen. My stepmother had texted, “Can you call us this weekend? Dad misses you.” I knew I should reply, maybe even call, but my mind was already tangled with preparations for the puja at my aunt’s house. As a Hindu, I was expected to be there early, help with the decorations, and join the prayers in my best kurta. The family would notice if I was late or distracted. But if I ignored my stepmother’s message, I’d be letting down my dad, who always tried so hard to make me feel included. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing on me—one asking for my presence and devotion, the other for my attention and care. My heart pounded as I tried to figure out how to be a good step-child and a devoted Hindu at the same time, knowing that whatever I chose, someone would be disappointed.
